title: Promoting Women in Science

author: Dunja Mladenić, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Can I start?
What's the plan?
Yes.
Are all the mikes fine?
Yeah I got three of them.
OK, hello, my name is Donya Bladin each I come from Department of Knowledge Technologies from years of Steven Institute.
So my background is computer science and what I do in research is data analysis, knowledge management, prediction, analysis of web semantic, web pencil.
Three months.
Yeah.
OK, you said better.
Sounds better OK thanks OK so.
But as a kind of addition to my regular research, I got somehow involved in the issues of women in science.
And one other thing I think it's useful to share with you is something about promoting women in science and some projects we had.
So let me go slowly through that to show you how I got into the.
Story and then show you what we did.
So here is some background we already heard about some European bodies just previously, but let me go a bit further back.
So there was eaten, which was an expert group of women in science which was set up.

But European Commission in 1998 and members were members of the group were from 10 Member states of the European Union and they were working on the report and they reported on how the position of women in Science in European Union.
But they were focusing primarily on Western.
Europe.
In parallel to that, there was established Helsinki Group of women scientists and there is a crucial difference between the two.
The first one is expert Group, so people were selected based on their expertise.
The second one is each country.
Assign a person to be a delegate in Helsinki Group.
So usually these are representatives of ministris or similar.
And they an Helsinki group continues to work and handles issue regarding women in science has regular yearly meeting sensor one.

And then there was another group which was expert Group and was expert Group established in 2002 by European Commission and for this expert group members were from Central and Eastern European countries and in that group I was representative of Slovenia.
And that's how I got involved in the whole story.
And my kind of motivation for that was all there is some expert group about women in science and there need to be some data collected and analyzed and so on.
Sounds like fun.
I like data analysis and I didn't expect that I will have to learn a lot about other things connected to women in science.
I had no clue about these three things before and so on.
So that was all new for me.
But you know, as a scientist, it was fun.
There were so many new things.
What was interesting for this expert group?
Was that there was a.
It was established because it was recognized that the Eaton report is not really easily transferable to central and Eastern European countries.
An report on invites countries reports of women scientists having all different kinds of issues and troubles which were mentioned in the previous talk.
And there was some recommendations from that report.
Maybe if I just highlight three of them, one was for national education policies.
To pay special attention to created to creating a general approach.
Supporting gender mainstreaming from elementary schools or to hire schools so it's about education and checking what's in education.
And it's that the program is also gender neutral.
The other one is universities and scientific institutions to have a specific person assigned to deal with issues so we made in science.
We had situations not so long ago that there were unclear situations.
What happens if you apply for PhD.
You get it approval.
You start working and go on maternity leave.
Is it like the this one year or whatever maternity leave?
Does it like put on hold or whatever you have time for till you finish your PhD or not and that will depending on faculties and so on.

And also the third recommendation was connected to media which also doesn't take doesn't report often on women in science and also probably not science as much as we would like to see a scientist so inspired by that envoys report there was.
A project in which I was involved European project.
Central establishing central European.
Center for Women and Youth in Science with several aims.
One was at promoting promoting gender equality and research and development, and also promoting young scientists and that was first first of such kind of regional center that was established.
The center also aimed and to advance position of women scientists and of young scientists in Central Europe, and there was a number of workshops and training organized.
There was user friendly website developed also a database of experts from Central Europe.
I guess that was for all different disciplines of science.

The database, one of the motivation for that was that sometimes on European project or some other committees, you hear that, well, we would take some women on board, but there are none with that expertise.
So this database had a, you know, get opportunity to women to register to show their expertise and also to have at least some argument saying no.
There are women with that expertise.
Here is a database, you know.
How much is going to pick up?
It's on the women.
You can't enforce something or someone.
And then another activity we switch in this Central European Center for Women and Youth in Science was promotion of women in science and I will talk about that later.
Actually, this triggered promotion of women in science into other projects and I will mention.
All three of them.
So another project in which I'm currently involved in women in science debate.
It has a general objective to stimulate policy and wider public debate on the situation and perspective of women in science.

Also bridge the gap between policy developments and public understanding of the related issues and raise gender event awareness among policymakers, scientists, as well as among the public interest and scientific developers.
So there are general objectives and there are some measurable, measurable objectives.
It's a two year, two year European project.
A supported by European Commission.
What we're doing there is also publishing 5 national reports that's on way so I can show you one.
And there's also to be national conferences, organized 5 conferences in all five countries which are participating and Sauvignon one is going to be this year later.
Um?
So both promotion activities, all these influenced and the kind of also enabled promotion activities in Slovenia.
So what we did one thing was trapped is traveling exhibition or Slovenian women information technologies and also virtual exhibition.
And of course that's because, you know, that's my area and that's where I had greatest chances to get some women participating in that.
Like my colleagues from University studies.
What we did is also a brochure.
So I brought a few witnessed so you are free to take them if you want.
Just give round one is English and one is Slovenian.
I'll give both around.
And if someone wants to leave some more at the table and wants to take it.
Um?
So we also after doing computer science we also we saw that it was like a great interest.
So we also went to electrical engineering mathematics.

And mechanical engineering and that selection was just by myself saying, well, let's see where we men are, by my judgment under represented, but what wasn't by my judgment was I said, OK, well if we're doing that, we should kind of be fair.
So we called universities.
In Slovenia, we contacted all universities in Slovenia asking them to give us names of all women which have PhD in all these four areas, and that was also nontrivial.

I mean, it sounds like trivial, but it took us months together, thinking that at the end I had a student going to University and sitting there and going through the books to find which women have a PhD in that.
But then we contacted all that we could, and.
You know, in some cases we got more feedback in some less, and the idea was if you look at the brochures.
Let me give some more on the other side.
Thank you so the idea was to promote women.
And also their personal views, but primarily to give them a chance to promote their research.
And that's also how we went into that activity.
Because you know, being in research myself, I wouldn't be happy if someone approached me and tell me where you are.
A woman in science, can you tell us about how you feel about being woman and how you feel about you?
Know well I'm in size, do you want to talk about my research and that's why we also structured that way at the same time give it opportunities.
Thank you.
If you want to share something with us about your personal experience.
You're also welcome.
So the the third thing we did on promotion was connecting that to another project, which is a completely, you know, computer science project.
It's on establishing European Wide Distributed Institute in principle methods of pattern analysis, statistical modeling and computational learning.
And there we we made a similar act.
Tivity on promoting women in size.
I'll show some websites so this is in Slovenia and that was the first exhibition we had for women in computer science.
And that's one of the examples how one of the entries looked.
So there we asked for a photo.

There is a description, first part of description was instructed to be about your research, but try to be kind of for general public so that different people can understand which is not so easy for us.
You know to write about our research in understandable way.
And then we also made a bit later, also English version and including as I said, also, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering and mathematics.
And you can see how many of man we got.
And also I think what is interesting is statistics at least till 2006 like for computer science there were 87 graduates.
So there are.
So I will read for you.
And 17 of them were women that certainly Anna University in electrical Engineering, 1929 women and 400 men received PhD.
That's all you've done in diversity.
I'm just simplifying at a mechanical engineering 252 credits with PhD, 11 of them where we met.
So I mean, you can see obviously that there is some kind of under represented.
And there is one example of electrical engineering.
And they will try to.
Show you actually on the website.
I think we'll have.
Better readability.
OK, so if you go here this is for computer science.
It's a bit better.
Yeah, it's larger.

OK, so it's taking awhile and if we look a little just just briefly into what what is in there so the first part says I decided to study computer science because I thought it could be compared to applied mathematics, which I had found very interesting already and so on.
So that's a kind of my motivation, and that was also one of the goals.
Tried also to inspire younger people to decide to go for this study because.

Put them forward.
OK, so that's a Slovenian site and this, as I mentioned, there is a traveling exhibition and this is the one like the thrilling investigation was opened in April 2006.
It's in Slovenian and it moves through universities and libraries.
And you know, different places where they welcome it and it's still on go.
And this is another.

Another part which I wanted to show you on the exhibit.

Which is including that promotion of women in science into European Network of excellence, which is this in statistical data analysis and pattern recognition and so on.
